title: Bad compiler error

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

body:
At the end of [this thread](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-by-example/issues/390), I saw

```
fn main() {
    if let Some(&pat) = Some(&Box::new(1)) {
        println!("{:?}", pat);
    }
}
```

With the error

```
error[E0507]: cannot move out of borrowed content
 --> ref.rs:2:17
  |
2 |     if let Some(&pat) = Some(&Box::new(1)) {
  |                 ^---
  |                 ||
  |                 |hint: to prevent move, use `ref pat` or `ref mut pat`
  |                 cannot move out of borrowed content
```

This error I don't think should've had that hint there. The hint is great when it's well-placed, but this time it doesn't make much sense, since it implies `&pat` should be replaced with `ref pat`. In the poster's case, autoderef handles `println!` even when `ref pat` is used, so perhaps the OP never noticed, but in many other cases this would cause issues. Using `ref pat` would cause `pat` to be of type `&&Box`, which isn't going to be the intent of the programmer.

I think what the compiler means here is that `pat` should be replaced with `ref pat`, which would be `&ref pat`, and yeah that's correct. `&ref pat` can always be simplified to `pat` itself, so basically the compiler should avoid outputting the hint whenever the erroring identifier comes after an `&` (Since that would always lead to a redundant `&ref` construct if the hint is followed).
